pages.transcription:
Aug. 1st 1864
My Dear Sir:
I have yours of the 30th.  It seems to me a great mistake that you have not ere this been in communication with the Commissioner of Internal Revenue respecting the tax to be paid on our book.  The law has been a month passed; all have known that it was about to be put in execution; yet here we are in August, and nothing has been done.
I will write to the Commissioner to-night; but we ought to have had his ear before now.
over

As we are now at the first of August, and have been sending out books for more than two months, I wish you would ? state an account with me and send me a check for so much (as nearly as you may) of copyright as may now be do me.  Of course, I want pay only for the volume already in your hands, or 12 1/2 cents for each volume sold.  I would like to receive a payment on account if it is not convenient to state an account at present.
I will try to make Lewis ease off at least on the printers and binders.
Yours,
Horace Greeley
O.D. Cose Esq. Hartford, Conn.
